captions.text: At the airport a very unusual passenger arrives
on a late night flight.
The badly hurt baby Dugong is
just days old.
It was found separated from his mum
off the coast of North Queensland.
This little guy is facing an uphill battle.
He's stressed and he needs around the clock feeding and attention.
It's probably a bit thin, a bit dehydrated
hasn't eaten for maybe days.
He probably got those wounds from the tusks of other males.
Calves that stay with their mums rarely suffer these nasty attacks.
He was probably orphaned shortly after his birth.
A check over reveals more wounds and a fresh umbilicus point.
Finally it is back in the water for his first feed.
It's a massive shock to his system to be without his mum
and out of the ocean.
But Sea World Dugong carer Wendy Blanchard
is patient.
It takes her all night
to get him to take even a little of the milk.
Which is a veterinary mammal formula
mixed with coconut cream for extra fat content
and some antibiotics
Dugong's are listed as a vulnerable species.
Over the past 30 years their numbers have plummeted
60 percent
The fact that this little one is starting to take the milk
is a good sign.

comments.text:
Dugongs are similar to Manatees but different in the fact that they are sea 
dwelling, and don't have the rounded tail of the Manatee. I have long said 
that man needs to be much more willing to help our friends in the sea as 
I've done for the past 10 to 15 years, if people don't act now to save our 
Ocean Planet by the time they do realize they were wrong all along it could 
very well be too late for our beautiful friends under the waves and in all 
the world's oceans!﻿

comments.text:
The majority of rescue operations like this aim for release after the 
animal has been deemed capable of survival. Because he's going to grow to 
associate people with food and care there's a good chance he will not be 
released back into the wild. However, in cases like that the animals are 
given very nice homes.

comments.text:
Dugong and Manatee are NOT the same, even when they look similar. That's 
like saying that leopard and lion are the same only because they both look 
like cats and live almost exactly the same way in Africa. Manatees are from 
the warm areas around the Caribbean. Dugongs are from the warm waters 
around all those Indonesian islands, even as far down as the Australian 
coast.﻿

comments.text:
+superDMTV Gonzalez So what do you suggest? To tell the truth I have a phd 
in engineering (particularly in water treatment) and I sometimes edit 
articles in wikipedia (which is relevant to my educational background). As 
far as I know, If you disagree with any statement in wikipedia, you can 
tell everybody about your disagreement and provide your own facts (with 
authoritative links, preferably in science journals). So I'm asking you, 
provide me the main differences between dugong and manatee? You may go to a 
library and check some information on this subject. And after that, maybe 
We will discuss...

comments.author: Stripe&lines Ghost

comments.text:
+blizzard0508 wikipedia states "Dugong dugon. It is the only living 
representative of the once-diverse family Dugongidae. It is also the only 
sirenian in its range, which spans the waters of at least 37 countries 
throughout the Indo-Pacific, though the majority of dugongs live in the 
northern waters of Australia between Shark Bay and Moreton Bay. The dugong 
is the only strictly marine herbivorous mammal, as all species of manatee 
use fresh water to some degree." By the way I like manatee so much, I wish 
one day I'll be in Florida to see them in wild nature.
comments.author: Pavel Tverdunov
